EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This material supersedes IRM 4.19.22, dated 04-20-2021.
Small Business-Self Employed
Table of Contents

) This section is designed to assist the clerical employees in the Small Business/ Self-Employed (SB/SE) Document Matching Combined Annual Wage Reporting (CAWR) operations with their responsibilities. (
) Purpose: To provide procedures for the clerical staff in the CAWR Operation. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are SB/SE clerical employees in the CAWR operation. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Exam Field and Campus Policy. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE BMF Document Matching. (
) Primary Stakeholder: SB/SE (
) Program Goals: Program goals for this type of work can be found in IRM
, CAWR Manager and Coordinator. (

) The Combined Annual Wage Reporting (CAWR) is a document matching program that compares the Federal Income Tax (FIT) withheld, Medicare wages, Social Security wages, and Social Security tips reported to the IRS the Forms
X and Form
Schedule H against the amounts reported to SSA via the processed totals of the Forms W-
, Wage and Tax Statement, the amounts reported to IRS on Forms
R, Distributions from Pension, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt Sharing Plans, and W-
G, Certain Gambling Winnings. When referring to all Form
, Form
, Form
, Form
, IRM will read

) The CAWR program has two basic components. The two components are the Internal Revenue Service -CAWR (IRS-CAWR) program and the Civil Penalty Program-CAWR (SSA-CAWR) . Note: When referring to IRS-CAWR cases, the reference will be IRS-CAWR. When referring to SSA-CAWR cases, the reference will be SSA-CAWR. When an instruction indicates CAWR, it is referring to all case types. (
) The success of the CAWR Operation and achieving service wide program goals depends directly on the work performed by the clerical staff. (

) CAWR clerks are called upon to multi-task in order for the CAWR units to function. Each clerk performs assigned tasks and on occasion will be directed to other phases of similar but not familiar activities. For that reason, cross training is essential. Note: CAWR units may not be identical, but the clerical support activity is uniform in nature. (

) The Combined Annual Tax Reporting System (CATRS) is a computer platform that houses the CAWR Automated Program (CAP). CAP is a computer applica- tion that houses the CAWR programs (inventory, correspondence, reporting, document preparation, and updated to Master File). CAWR clerks will update CAP during the CAWR process. (

) This clerical section has been written as a guide regarding most of the common duties and assignments of a clerk. It is not all-inclusive. The following subsections outline speciﬁc tasks to be performed by the clerical staff.

) Scope and Objectives (

) This section is designed to assist the clerical employees in the Small Business/ Self-Employed (SB/SE) Document Matching Combined Annual Wage Reporting (CAWR) operations with their responsibilities. (
) Purpose: To provide procedures for the clerical staff in the CAWR Operation. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are SB/SE clerical employees in the CAWR operation. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Exam Field and Campus Policy. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE BMF Document Matching. (
) Primary Stakeholder: SB/SE (
) Program Goals: Program goals for this type of work can be found in IRM
, CAWR Manager and Coordinator.
) Background (

) The Combined Annual Wage Reporting (CAWR) is a document matching program that compares the Federal Income Tax (FIT) withheld, Medicare wages, Social Security wages, and Social Security tips reported to the IRS the Forms
X and Form
Schedule H against the amounts reported to SSA via the processed totals of the Forms W-
, Wage and Tax Statement, the amounts reported to IRS on Forms
R, Distributions from Pension, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt Sharing Plans, and W-
G, Certain Gambling Winnings. When referring to all Form

) The CAWR program has two basic components. The two components are the Internal Revenue Service -CAWR (IRS-CAWR) program and the Civil Penalty Program-CAWR (SSA-CAWR) . Note: When referring to IRS-CAWR cases, the reference will be IRS-CAWR. When referring to SSA-CAWR cases, the reference will be SSA-CAWR. When an instruction indicates CAWR, it is referring to all case types.
The success of the CAWR Operation and achieving service wide program goals depends directly on the work performed by the clerical staff.
CAWR clerks are called upon to multi

task in order for the CAWR units to function. Each clerk performs assigned tasks and on occasion will be directed to other phases of similar but not familiar activities. For that reason, cross training is essential.
Note: CAWR units may not be identical, but the clerical support activity is uniform in nature.
The Combined Annual Tax Reporting System (CATRS) is a computer platform that houses the CAWR Automated Program (CAP). CAP is a computer applica

tion that houses the CAWR programs (inventory, correspondence, reporting, document preparation, and updated to Master File). CAWR clerks will update CAP during the CAWR process. This clerical section has been written as a guide regarding most of the common duties and assignments of a clerk. It is not all
inclusive. The following subsections outline speciﬁc tasks to be performed by the clerical staff.
The authority is covered under Pub. L. No. 94-202, sec. 232, 89 Stat. 1135 (1976) (codiﬁed at 42 U.S.C. Sec. 432).

In addition, taxpayers may also respond to Letter 2057C closing letters, adjust- ment notices, notices of intent to levy, or balance due notices. Further research
may be needed to identify and process these cases IRM
, Re- searching on IDRS. (
) Correspondence may be received by mail, fax and/or referrals. (

) CAWR cases can be deﬁned as Reply, Reconsideration (Recon)(previously called Late Reply), or Prior Recon (previously called Late Reply). a. A Reply is any case with a current notice as listed above. This case will not be accompanied by any other notices and will not have an assess- ment or penalty applied. The cases are typically in “M” status in IDRS and do not have a closing date on CAP if applicable. b. A Recon (previously called Late Reply): May have a current notice but will be accompanied by another notice. It will have tax and/or penalty sessment. The status in IDRS is most likely closed or in suspense and applicable it will have a closing date on CAP. c. A Prior Recon (previously called Late Reply) is any case no longer on CAP. It will have the same characteristics as a Recon (previously called Late Reply). It will have tax or a penalty assessment and the correspon- dence may include a bill. You may have to do extensive research for case type in IDRS utilizing command codes such as BMFOLI, BMFOLU, BMFOLT, etc. Incoming (
) Upon receipt of all correspondence:
Stamp correspondence with the date received in the CAWR area.
Determine if the correspondence is in response to a CAWR discrepancy case. Example: Letter
C or Letter
C.
Sort correspondence by IRS-CAWR or SSA-CAWR case type. Reply Procedures (
) When batching and controlling work, look at the date the letter was issued. this date is close to

days prior to the current date, this notice can go into “No Reply” status soon. These cases need to be put on the CAP system im- mediately to avoid the case being assessed prior to the STAUP being input. receipts must be controlled by the later of
calendar days from the earliest IRS received date or
business days from receipt into the department. (
) The IRS received date is determined by following the priority criteria listed below:
Oldest received date stamped on correspondence. If there isn’t a received date (other than the CAWR stamped date) then use,
Envelope postmark date.
Signature date.
Current date. (
) To Control the Receipts:
On CAP, click on “EDIT”
Choose “Reply/Undeliverable Rcvd”
Click “Reply”
Enter earliest IRS received date
Enter EIN and Tax Period
Click “QUERY” Control

CAWR cases can be deﬁned as Reply, Reconsideration (Recon)(previously called Late Reply), or Prior Recon (previously called Late Reply).
a. A Reply is any case with a current notice as listed above. This case will not be accompanied by any other notices and will not have an assess

ment or penalty applied. The cases are typically in “M” status in IDRS and do not have a closing date on CAP if applicable. b. A Recon (previously called Late Reply): May have a current notice but will be accompanied by another notice. It will have tax and/or penalty sessment. The status in IDRS is most likely closed or in suspense and applicable it will have a closing date on CAP. c. A Prior Recon (previously called Late Reply) is any case no longer on CAP. It will have the same characteristics as a Recon (previously called Late Reply). It will have tax or a penalty assessment and the correspon
dence may include a bill. You may have to do extensive research for this case type in IDRS utilizing command codes such as BMFOLI, BMFOLU, BMFOLT, etc.

, Controlling on IDRS. (

) All replies, Recons (previously called late replies) and prior Recons (previously called late replies) must be controlled accurately and timely. Efficient inventory management is essential to meeting your program objectives. (
) Clerical management must set up and maintain an Inventory Management process to ensure: a. A batch consists of no more than

cases of the same program and received date. Note: Small volumes of work may be batched together into one batch, the received dates must be within seven calendar days of the earliest IRS received date. b. Each batch will be recorded and tracked utilizing a separate log for program. c. Each batch must be assigned in received date order. d. Each batch number is built according to the program type as outlined IRM
, Batching and Controlling Replies, IRM
, Batching and Controlling Recons (previously called Late Replies) and IRM

, Batching and Controlling Prior Recons (previously called Late Replies). e. Designate speciﬁc IDRS numbers to maintain your reply, Recon (previ- ously called late reply) and prior Recon (previously called late reply) inventory. Reminder: The CAWR/FUTA Integrated Automation Technology (IAT) Batcher

If Then there is a TC 290 on MFT 30 with blocking series 05 or 07 this is identiﬁed as a IRS-CAWR case. there is no adjustment on the SSN research the EIN for TC 240 adjustment with a PRN 549 or PRN 550 this is identiﬁed as an SSA-CAWR case.

b. Each batch will be recorded and tracked utilizing a separate log for each program. c. Each batch must be assigned in received date order. d. Each batch number is built according to the program type as outlined in IRM
, Batching and Controlling Replies, IRM
, Batching and Controlling Recons (previously called Late Replies) and IRM

, Batching and Controlling Prior Recons (previously called Late Replies). e. Designate speciﬁc IDRS numbers to maintain your reply, Recon (previ- ously called late reply) and prior Recon (previously called late reply) inventory.
Reminder: The CAWR/FUTA Integrated Automation Technology (IAT) Batcher Tool must be used for this process. The tool streamlines the

clerical process in batching and controlling cases directly to IDRS. It allows the user the option to send interim Letter 5825C on prior year cases, automatically input the applicable STAUP or TC 470/90 on all cases, and alerts the clerical staff of a case when it has an ASED expiring within 90 days. Use of this tool is mandatory.

) When a case is worked by the ﬁeld, the Revenue Officer (RO) will send a Form

Request for Adjustment, to request an abatement of the CAWR assessment and/or civil penalty. These requests will either be paper, fax, or a secure E-mail mailbox. The RO will put the taxpayer’s Name Control, MFT, and the last four digits of the TIN in the subject line of the E-mail to the speciﬁc Form

C that are returned undeliverable. Undeliverable mail received from the mail room can be identiﬁed one of two ways: a. Unopened original CAWR correspondence. b. An opened original CAWR correspondence with the envelope affixed to the back. (
) All letters
C or
C undeliverable mail is to be researched for a better address within
calender days of receipt. If a better address isn’t found the case must be controlled within those same
days to stop the suspense time frame from expiring. (

) Check the envelope for a yellow Post Office (P.O.) forwarding sticker. If a yellow sticker is present, compare the entity on the yellow sticker to the name and address using CC ENMOD to verify it is the same taxpayer. If so, then determine if the address on the USPS yellow sticker is more current than the address on ENMOD. If the USPS sticker is more current use the address to reissue the letter. (

) When there is not a PO forwarding sticker present, research IDRS for a new/ better address. A new/better address may be found using Command Codes ENMOD, INOLES, NAMEE, and BRTVUE. Reminder: Use of the Research Address IAT tool is mandatory for new address

) A statute of limitation is a time period established by law to review, analyze and resolve taxpayer and/or IRS related issues. The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) requires that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) will assess, refund, credit, and collect taxes within speciﬁc time limits. These limits are known the Statutes of Limitations. When they expire, the IRS can no longer assess additional tax, allow a claim for refund or credit by the taxpayer, or take collec- tion action. The determination of Statute expiration differs for Assessment, Refund, and Collection. (

) Failure to protect an assessment statute can result in disciplinary action against the responsible employee. The responsible area/employee is identiﬁed as the area/employee that had the case, when the case was within
days the ASED and either took no action to protect the statute or allowed the to expire (barred statute). (
) For CAWR clerical a Statute imminent case is identiﬁed by the Assessment Statute Expiration Date (ASED) which is
years from the due date of the return. (Example
tax year returns were due by
; therefore the ASED for
cases will be
). The ASED can be found on IDRS command code TXMOD or command code BMFOLT. Control

(4) The CAWR Batcher Tool will assist you in identifying a statute tax year case. The tool will not batch the case and it will print it out on the error listing with ASED in the remarks section. These cases will be manually batched and con- trolled on IDRS to a designated management official who will be responsible for making sure the case is reviewed and/or worked immediately to protect the statute. (5) To manually batch these cases use the following procedures: For Input Command Code Acton Then IRS-CAWR cases 1. InputC#,TYIRSXXXXXX,A,TPLR. 2. Control the case to the 10 digit IDRS number of the designated management official with the correct IRS received date. For SSA-CAWR cases 1. InputC#TYSSAXXXXX,A,TPLR. 2. Control the case to the 10 digit IDRS number of the designated management official with the correct IRS received date.

) Clerical function is responsible for all outgoing mail. This mail may consist of internal mail, misdirected mail, or external mail. (
) Internal mail is routed to other areas using a Form
, Document Transmit- tal. The receiving area will acknowledge the receipt of the cases by sending signed copy of the Form
back to the originating area. These forms must be maintained in a log in the CAWR unit. (

) At times misdirected mail may be received. Mail not related to the CAWR program will be routed back to the mail room for proper routing if the mail room was in error routing it to you. If the letter was addressed to CAWR and did not ﬁt CAWR criteria, forward to the proper area and issue an Letter
C the taxpayer. For additional information on issuing
C letters see IRM
,Referring Taxpayer Inquiries/Forms to Another Office. Also see http://serp.enterprise.irs.gov/content/who-where/who-where.html for instructions in routing misrouted. (
) When the TEs complete their daily work it is ﬁled in brown folders. Follow local procedures for routing these folders to the Files Function. (

, Closed Case Result Sheet for Returned SSA Cases and Form

as a batch cover. All Forms
and Forms
, (with attached paper Forms W-

Taxpayers may request assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS). TAS is an independent organization within the IRS created by Congress to help taxpayers resolve problems with the IRS and recommend changes to prevent the problems. Form
, Operations Assistance Requests (OARs), are received from TAS in the Clerical Function by both mail and fax. When a Form
is received in CAWR, it must be treated in an expeditious manner. Clerical should take the following actions for all OARs received:
Date Stamp each Form
Hand carry these cases to the TAS Liaison in your Unit or Functional Area.
Cash and non-cash remittances found outside of the Receipt and Control secured/restricted area are “discovered remittances.”
Immediately notify your manager/lead. Access CC INOLES to verify the name. At the bottom of the CC INOLES screen type the MFT, YEAR/Quarter,
, Rec’d date, and money amount. Print three copies of the CC INOLES screen. One attached to the case and two attached to the Remittance. Complete a Form
“Payment Posting Voucher.” Hand carry both the remittance, Form
and INOLES prints to your Manager.
Any loose Forms W-2 or Form 8922 received into the department need to be researched on CAP:

If And Then There is a case on CAP it is assigned to a TE give the Forms W-2 or Form 8922 to the TE assigned to the case. There is a case on CAP it is not assigned to TE give the Forms W-2 or Form 8922 to your lead for further research. If there is not a case on CAP N/A give the Forms W-2 or Form 8922 to your lead for further research.
Schedule D “Report of Discrepancies Caused by Acquisitions, Statutory Mergers, or Consolidations” information is now stored in the CAP system for all tax years. Loose paper Forms
Schedule D are routed to Philadelphia Service Center (PSC) CAWR. These Forms will be entered into the CAP system by a designated employee by following these procedures:

Schedule D “Report of Discrepancies Caused by Acquisitions, Statutory Mergers, or Consolidations” information is now stored in the CAP system for all tax years. Loose paper Forms 941 Schedule D are routed to Philadelphia Service Center (PSC) CAWR. These Forms will be entered into the CAP system by a designated employee by following these procedures:
Click “edit”. Select TE Miscellaneous and then “CAWR
Click on “Plus Sign”.
Enter the EIN.
Enter the tax period.
Enter the other party EIN.
Enter the transaction date.
Click “YES” when prompted to apply the record.
Destroy the paper Schedule D.
Note: If the Schedule D contains missing information that makes it impossible to input they can be placed in classiﬁed waste.

At times taxpayers or internal IRS areas may call to inquire about a issue. The clerical team will be responsible for retrieving and recording formation left on voice mail. On a telephone message slip record the following information: a. Date and time of call. b. Name of individual calling and company name. c. Phone number and extension. d. Best time to reach caller. e. EIN and tax period. f. A brief explanation of issue. g. The name of the clerk retrieving the message. When the case has an open “A” control on IDRS place the message
